audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing his tax rate and how it compares to others in his office. He mentions paying 17.7% while the office average was 32.9%, emphasizing that he doesn't engage in tax planning or have tax shelters, he just follows the instructions of the U.S. Congress.

The audio begins with a female speaker announcing a report indicating that Warren Buffet is not alone in receiving favorable tax deals, revealing that numerous Fortune 500 companies paid little or no taxes in recent years. She emphasizes the disparity, noting that ordinary individuals paid more in federal income taxes than corporations such as Wells Fargo or General Electric. She expresses shock at the fact that average person paid more in taxes than the named companies combined. The tone is informational but becomes increasingly critical and frustrated.

The clip begins with a female speaker discussing Wells Fargo considering becoming "you," noting that one downside is "you actually pay more income tax than they do." She mentions a "zillionaire" taking "your side," speaking in a neutral, informational tone. Background music then starts, giving off a suspenseful mood. The clip is then overtaken by an echoing noise.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing Bill Gates' urging of the world's major economies to support "a financial transaction tax." He notes the US previously had such a tax from "1914 to the mid-60s." Continuing in a straightforward and informative tone, he describes the idea as "a very, very small tax," around "a quarter of a percent on financial trades."

The audio clip begins with a female speaker reporting news, mentioning "National Nurses United" marching in Washington in support of a "financial transaction tax." She also notes that Democrats Tom Harkin and Peter DeFazio have introduced a bill to reinstate the tax, delivered in a neutral, informative tone.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker discussing an idea that is getting vocal support. She mentions the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Pope's official Catholic Church statement, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and French President Nicolas Sarkozy. Her tone is informative and professional.

The clip opens with a single female speaker discussing international political figures and their positions on possible bank fees or taxes, referring to a book and an interview. She describes Lawrence Summer's former opposition to an idea. She highlights a specific demand from various figures, including the Pope, American nurses, Bill Gates, and the German Chancellor. The speaker uses a conversational and informative tone. The clip ends with a question that suggests something seems doable.

The clip begins with a female host thanking Michael Moore for staying for an interview. Michael Moore responds, saying "Yes, it's thank you, it's doable." His tone is positive and affirmative. He continues, describing something as "very easy to do", "simple" and "not all everybody trying to get their claws into the rich".

The clip features a single male speaker passionately discussing economic policies. He mentions "a half a penny or a quarter of a penny" per dollar on stock market transactions, arguing it could generate significant revenue, specifically "350 billion dollars a year." He connects this to war spending, suggesting savings could be redirected. He believes Democrats should push this policy and calls it a "half a penny per dollar" that used to be taxed.

The clip begins with a female speaker explaining her desire to talk to "Michael" because he's been visiting occupied protests and thinks strategically about how America changes, especially on issues deemed unchangeable. Her tone is conversational and inquisitive. The audio then ends, without introducing any music or background sounds.
A woman speaks in an inquisitive tone, discussing the specificity of the demands of the "Occupy protesters," mentioning broad agendas versus specific calls for taxes.

A male speaker begins discussing the support for Occupy Wall Street, stating that many people are waiting for "marching orders" and mentioning resolutions to reinstate Glass-Steagall and remove Bush tax cuts. He speaks in a serious and informative tone, suggesting a sense of urgency and importance. The audio contains no music or background sounds.

The clip features one male speaker discussing taxation, highlighting the perceived ease of the topic. He mentions taxing, and focuses on the FICA and social security taxes, criticizing the fact that wealthy people earning over $110,000 pay zero social security or FICA tax, contrasting it with the 7% tax taken from someone making $40,000. He labels this as a simple idea and mentions Obama's past support for it.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing a movement, emphasizing the need to keep it broad, focusing on specific things, and pushing Congress and the president. He notes that the movement is growing, gaining more support each week. He believes good things will come out of it, but anticipates pushback, expressing optimism despite potential challenges. A female interviewer then acknowledges the speaker as Michael Moore, filmmaker, and author, thanking him for his time. The speaker thanks her in return. The interviewer announces they will be right back. There is also background music playing throughout the conversation.
